awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Physics REU and RET Programs at the University of Notre Dame
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and the Research Experience for Teachers (RET) site at the University of Notre Dame. The goal of the site is to provide realistic research experiences to undergraduate students and high school physics teachers. The primary impact is in training of the next generation of scientists who will be essential for the continued well being of our society and economy, and for maintaining a robust national defense. Taking it a step further, the RET component aims at creating enthusiastic high school teachers who, in turn, will convey the excitement of physics to their students, the future physicists.
 
The participants will work with a faculty mentor on a specific research project and will be exposed to physics research in other areas via weekly seminars, workshops, interactions with other participants, and field trips to nearby national laboratories. They will participate in a "Physics Olympics" with REUs from Purdue and Michigan State Universities, prepare a research report at the end of the program, and make oral presentations at the REU-RET Symposium. They will also maintain a research logbook and will have the opportunity to attend courses in computer programming and radiation safety, as well as a GRE-preparation class and an "Applying to Graduate School" workshop . A series of workshops will also be held as part of the Ethics component. Projects will be available in the areas of Astronomy, Astrophysics, Biophysics, Cosmology, Condensed Matter Physics, High-Energy Particle Physics, Nuclear Physics, and Physics Education Research.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Notre Dame Physics REU and RET program provides an opportunity for undergraduate physics majors and high-school teachers each summer to discover the excitement of physics research. We attempt to create a 'physics community' that includes senior scientists, graduate students and young postdocs, undergraduate students, physics teachers, and high school students.

The participants worked with faculty members on specific research projects and were exposed to physics research in other areas via weekly seminars, workshops, interactions with other participants, and field trips to nearby national laboratories. They prepared a research report at the end of the program and made oral presentations at the REU-RET Symposium. They also maintained a research logbook and had an opportunity to attend courses in computer programming, GRE Preparation, scientific writing, and radiation safety. Ethics Workshops formed another integral component of the program.

A total of 72 REU students were supported by this grant, of whom 38 (53%) were women and 32 (44%) were from under-represented minority groups. 51 (71%) of the supported students came from institutions where opportunities for meaningful research are minimal, or non-existent. More than 70% of REU participants have gone on to pursue graduate studies and research. In addition, 53 participants (including 29 international students) were supported from other funds.

The RET program, typically, had 12 high school teachers every Summer. They came mostly from within a 50-km radius centered at Notre Dame, but some participants also came from places as far away as New Jersey. Several teachers have leveraged their experiences from the RET program to contribute to physics outreach in high schools in Chile, Mexico, and the Far East. The RET participants regularly took on a considerable role in the regional science outreach program called ?Science Alive,? held annually at the St. Joseph County Public Library in downtown South Bend.

During the summer of 2020, we adapted our usual summer activities in order to comply with COVID health and safety guidelines. We developed a two-week, zoom-based online course for several dozen rising high school seniors. The course covered kinematics, dynamics, special relativity, PYTHON programming and analysis of particle physics data.
